paper_id: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems

paper_metadata.title: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Potassium management, soil dynamics, crop uptake, rice systems

research_methodology.experimental_design: Randomized Block Design (RBD) with three replications and nine treatments.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: at the beginning of the experiment, mid-season at 30 and 60 DAT, and after harvest

spatial_scope.geographic_coverage: Central Research Station of Orissa University of Agriculture and Technology (OUAT), Bhubaneswar, India
site_characteristics: Eastern and South-Eastern Coastal Plain agroclimatic zone
spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: Findings aim to inform nutrient management strategies for similar agroecological contexts.

controls_and_treatments: T5: 20 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + 3 t ha⁻¹ straw
T6: 30 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + 3 t ha⁻¹ straw
T7: 40 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + 3 t ha⁻¹ straw
T9: 40 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + 1% KNO₃ foliar spray at panicle initiation stage

measurement_protocols: Exchangeable potassium: ammonium acetate method (Hanway and Heidel, 1952)
Reserve potassium: nitric acid extraction (Wood and De Turk, 1941)
Non-exchangeable potassium: procedure described by Black (1965)
Nitrogen content: alkaline KMnO4 (Subbiah and Asija, 1956)

primary_measurements.parameter: Initial Soil Exchangeable Potassium (1 N NH4OAc-K)

primary_measurements.measurement_context: 0–15-cm soil depth (corresponding increases at deeper depths)
0–15-cm soil depth (corresponding increases at deeper depths)
Total K added across dry and wet seasons for T1-T9 respectively
Total K removed across dry and wet seasons for T1-T9 respectively
Total K balance across dry and wet seasons for T1-T9 respectively

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Greater shift in non-exchangeable K in the dry season, indicating larger soil K depletion.

comparative_results.practical_significance: T9 yield: 3.8 t ha⁻¹ (dry), 5.4 t ha⁻¹ (wet); T1 yield: 2.7 t ha⁻¹ (dry), 4.2 t ha⁻¹ (wet)

groups_compared: Reduced fertilizer doses + straw (T5, T6, T7)
comparative_results.practical_significance: Positive K balance with reduced fertilizer + straw (53, 65, 89 kg ha⁻¹), negative K balance with chemical fertilizers alone (-60, -87, -86 kg ha⁻¹)

regions: Eastern and South-Eastern Coastal Plain agroclimatic zone
geographic_details.landscape_position: Central Research Station of Orissa University of Agriculture and Technology (OUAT)

precipitation_patterns.seasonality: approximately 70% occurring between July and September

physical_properties.drainage: poorly drained during the rainy season but moderately well drained during the summer

land_use_context.historical_context: Green Revolution led to intensified nutrient depletion in soils.

rates.nitrogen: 80 kg N ha⁻¹ (30 kg N ha⁻¹ basal + 50 kg N ha⁻¹ split)
rates.potassium_straw: ~45 kg K ha⁻¹ (from 3 t ha⁻¹ straw)

timing: Additional N: two splits (2:1 ratio) at 20 and 50 days after transplanting (DAT)
MOP K: two equal splits at basal application and 50 DAT
KNO₃ foliar spray: at the panicle initiation stage

irrigation.system_type: puddled, transplanted rice system (implies flooded conditions)

other_practices.tillage: puddled, power tiller to shallow depth, second plowing after 15 days (for straw decomposition)
other_practices.pest_management: SAAF (2 g L⁻¹), streptocycline (0.15 g L⁻¹), Furadan (10 kg acre⁻¹)

balance_calculations.K_balance: K added - K removed (range: -140 to 89 kg ha⁻¹)

study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Multiple time points within each season

seasonal_variations.seasonal_pattern: Wet season yields generally higher than dry season yields across treatments.
Greater shift in non-exchangeable K observed in the dry season.

methodological_strengths: Randomized Block Design (RBD) with three replications
Evaluation of nine diverse K management treatments
Assessment of different K forms (exchangeable, non-exchangeable, reserve K)
Coverage of two distinct seasons (dry and wet) in a rice-rice system
methodological_limitations: Details on plant sampling and analysis methods are incomplete in the provided text.
Study conducted at a single experimental site.
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: Incomplete information on plant sampling and analysis methods.

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Single site in Odisha, India, but findings are suggested to be relevant for similar agroecological contexts.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: Covers two distinct seasons (dry and wet) within a year, reflecting seasonal dynamics.
representativeness.system_representativeness: Focuses on a puddled, transplanted rice-rice system, which is a common and important agricultural system in the region.

comparative_studies: Sreekanth et al., 2017; Singh et al., 2021 (rice productivity challenges)
Srinivasarao et al., 2011; Sanyal et al., 2014 (K deficiency in Indian soils)
Kumar et al., 2018 (negative soil K balance)
Attanandana et al., 2010 (K removal rates by rice)
Saha et al., 2009; Mohapatra et al., 2017 (recommended K dose)
Das et al., 2022 (depletion of K forms)
Rao and Srinivas, 2017 (non-exchangeable and reserve K contribution)
Lalitha and Dhakshinamoorthy, 2014; Alomar and Jena, 2023 (soil's ability to release non-exchangeable K)
Gupta et al., 2007; Chivenge et al., 2020 (straw incorporation benefits)
Witt et al., 1999; Hou et al., 2021 (reduced fertilizer + straw for K balance)
Brar and Brar, 2004; Adhikari et al., 2019 (foliar K application benefits)
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: Potassium is an essential macronutrient for rice growth and productivity, involved in enzyme activation, osmoregulation, and photosynthesis. Intensive rice farming leads to K depletion, necessitating integrated nutrient management strategies that consider exchangeable, non-exchangeable, and reserve K dynamics for sustainable production.
benchmarking_data: Rice K removal: ~24 kg K₂O per ton of grain produced (Attanandana et al., 2010)
Recommended K dose for wetland rice in India: 40–60 kg K₂O per hectare (Saha et al., 2009; Mohapatra et al., 2017)

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: Rich in experimental design, soil properties, treatment details, and quantitative results (yield, K balance). Less detailed on specific statistical outputs beyond significance and LSD, and plant analysis methods are incomplete.
potential_ambiguities: The exact duration of the study (e.g., number of years) is not explicitly stated, only the seasons covered.
Quantification of 'corresponding increases' for non-exchangeable and reserve K at deeper soil depths is not provided.
extraction_limitations: The 'Plant sampling and analysis' section was incomplete in the provided text, limiting extraction of those details.
recommended_validation_checks: If possible, verify the exact calculation of K balance based on K added and K removed, although the final balance values are provided.

results.paper_id: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems.pdf
